keyTakeAways: George Santos, a former U.S. Representative from New York, was released from prison after President Donald Trump commuted his seven-year sentence for fraud charges.
Santos dismissed criticism as political, claiming he had earned a 'very large slice of humble pie' during his time in prison and that his sentence was not politically motivated.
Former colleagues like Rep. Nick LaLota and Rep. Andrew Garbarino criticized Santos, calling his actions criminal and asserting that his short prison term was insufficient justice.
Santos stated he is no longer required to pay fines, restitution, or serve probation and will do his best to comply with legal obligations.
He claims he did not commit fraud and that the investment to win an election was legitimate, asserting he was in a 'chaotic ball of flames' at the time of the fraud allegations.
Santos expressed interest in prison reform, citing experiences in solitary confinement and stating he would support reform efforts in a non-partisan way.
He declined to return to politics, stating he is 'all politicked out' and does not see himself reentering public office in the next decade.

summaryOfNewsArticle: George Santos, a former U.S. Representative from New York, was released from prison after President Donald Trump commuted his seven-year sentence for fraud charges. Despite facing widespread criticism from fellow Republicans like Nick LaLota and Andrew Garbarino, who argue that his actions warranted harsher punishment, Santos claims his sentence was not politically motivated and asserts he has earned remorse through his time in prison. He says he is now focused on prison reform and does not plan to return to politics in the foreseeable future, stating he is 'all politicked out.' He also denies fraud, maintaining that his actions were driven by a chaotic political environment and that he will do what the law requires regarding restitution, though no further financial obligations are currently imposed.
title: George Santos maintains his prosecution was political, says he’s had a ‘very large slice of humble pie’
